Estimating economic losses in a displacement crisis is complex and highly political. In some cases, the host population may actually be benefitting from the displacement when the displacement is creating jobs, increasing the demand, etc. Last data reporting Lebanon's economic losses due to the crisis goes back to the end of 2015: Lebanon was estimated to have lost USD 18.15 billion following the lowering of the GDP growth rate and USD 4.2 billion due to the lower revenues received between 2012 and 2015 (TOTAL: USD 22.53 billion).  However, due to the reasons listed above, the indicator was xed.

Calculations based on HNO and Humanitarian Access Report Data: combining report access map on 5 access severity levels with the HNO PIN data for migrants and refugees. Migrants and refugees in need living in admin level 1 areas on level 4 and 5 are considered as facing restricted access constraints; migrants and refugees in need living in admin level 1 areas on level 2 and 3 are considered as facing limited access constraints. Level 1 areas were not included in the figures. This is a general estimation which does not reflect the specific access challenges per district or distinguish between different categories of migrants and refugees in need. The usage of OCHA level 4 and 5 for restricted access constraints and level 2 and 3 for limited access constraint is also an attempt to translate OCHA's 5 severity levels into ACAPS' two  categories. For these reasons, reliability is set as low for both access indicators as the above figures are most likely an overestimation and no specific figure for migrants and refugees in need affected by access constraints was found.

While refugee settlements are limited to specific provinces, only 4% of the 780,000 registered Afghan refugees in Iran live in 20 refugee settlements. The vast majority live in urban areas. An additional 2 million undocumented Afghans also live in urban areas. To avoid making a dramatic overestimate, the top 3 refugee-hosting regions are used to determine the geographic and human exposure to the refugee situation. This includes the provinces of Tehran, Isfahan, and Khorasan Razavi. This is still an overestimate.

Although undocumented Afghans and Afghan refugees are located throughout the country, it is assumed that not the entire country is actually exposed or affected by the crisis. To avoid making a dramatic overestimate, the top 3 refugee-hosting regions are used to determine the geographic and human exposure to the refugee situation. This includes the provinces of Tehran, Isfahan, and Khorasan Razavi. This is still an overestimate.

The PIN is 10.4 million as assessed by the 2020 Needs and Priorities Overview. There is no Level 1 because everyone exposed is considered affected. Level 2 is the entire country population (25 million) minus the PIN. Level 3 includes the PIN, minus those considered in severe need. Level 4 includes those considered especially vulnerable and experiencing higher needs - this is calculated using the target PIN figure, which also includes 1.7 million children under 5. Given that the biggest needs relate to food and nutrition, this population is considered especially vulnerable. There is no one considered to be on Level 5.

Crisis: Lake Chad basin crisis in Niger

Crisis: Lake Chad basin crisis in Niger

Crisis: Lake Chad basin crisis in Niger

Crisis: Lake Chad basin crisis in Niger

Total population is considered affected by the various crises

Source and Date: Needs and Priorities 2020 ; world population review Accessed 12/08/23
Justification: The PIN is 10.4 million as assessed by the 2020 Needs and Priorities Overview. There is no Level 1 because everyone exposed is considered affected. Level 2 is the entire country population (26 million) minus the PIN. Level 3 includes the PIN, minus those considered in severe need. Level 4 includes those considered especially vulnerable and experiencing higher needs - this is calculated using the target PIN figure, which also includes 1.7 million children under 5. Given that the biggest needs relate to food and nutrition, this population is considered especially vulnerable. There is no one considered to be on Level 5.

Given that the biggest needs relate to food and nutrition, this population is considered especially vulnerable. There is no one considered to be on Level 5.

Justification:
Since violence in Sudan escalated on 15 April, 6083 people have been injured, according to the Sudanese Federal
Ministry of Health and as reported by WHO.

During Whole of Afghanistan (WoA) assessment in 2022, the assessment covered all 34 provinces and achieved representative results for all urban and rural areas,
with the exception of Kandahar city due to access constraints. It implies that the population in Kandahar city are facing restricted access constraint.
Over 21,300 buildings sustained damage due to earthquake
Over 3,330 homes destroyed due to earthquakes
Total number of injuries because of the earthquakes.
The total number of deaths because of the earthquakes between 7 and 11 October
Total population of the country.

Source and Date: UN RC Nepal and UNCT Nepal 10/11/2023; City Population accessed 09/11/2023
Justification: The earthquake was felt in the provinces of Karnali, Lumbini, Gandaki, and Sudurpaschim. The landmass affected is the total landmass of these provinces.

The Free Papua Movement has led an insurgency movement calling for the independence of the West Papua territory (currently comprising six provinces of Central Papua, Highland Papua, Papua, South Papua, Southwest Papua, and West Papua) since the early 1960s when Indonesia annexed the Dutch-controlled territory. While certain areas are more affected by violence than others, the recurrence of violence, protests, and reports of severe restrictions in different parts of the Papuan provinces indicates that the entire population is affected to a certain degree.

The Free Papua Movement has led an insurgency movement calling for the independence of the West Papua territory (currently comprising six provinces of Central Papua, Highland Papua, Papua, South Papua, Southwest Papua, and West Papua) since the early 1960s when Indonesia annexed the Dutch-controlled territory. While certain areas are more affected by violence than others, the recurrence of violence, protests, and reports of severe restrictions in different parts of the provinces in the West Papua territory indicates that the entire population is affected to a certain degree.

Clashes between armed separatist groups and the military have led to a violent crackdown against both separatists and civilians. Indonesian rule in West Papua territory (currently comprising six provinces of Central Papua, Highland Papua, Papua, South Papua, Southwest Papua, and West Papua) is marked by human rights violations against the ethnic Melanesian population. There have been reports of security force abuses including extrajudicial killings, torture, arbitrary detention, and mistreatment of peaceful protesters. It is therefore considered that all people living in the affected area are affected by the crisis.

Access in West Papua territory (currently comprising six provinces of Central Papua, Highland Papua, Papua, South Papua, Southwest Papua, and West Papua) is restricted by authorities, and IDP number is compiled by human right observers in the region. INGOs/UN have no access. According to the UN source: "since the escalation of violence in December 2018, the overall number of displaced has grown by 60,000 to 100,000 people." As at 6 October 2023, the number of IDPs in the West Papua territory was estimated to be around 76,000 by an international human rights watchdog.

The majority of IDPs have not returned to their homes due to the heavy security force presence and ongoing armed clashes in the conflict areas. Information on IDP figures in West Papua is not always available on a regular basis, and the UN is considered a reliable source, so although the range is between 60,000 - 100,000, the analyst's interpretation is that the number is likely closer to 100,000 IDPs.
No data available.

This is the only crisis in Iran, and It is unlikely that there are any fatalities caused directly by the refugee crisis. However, it can be assumed that premature deaths do accur in the refugee population due to access constraints and poor living conditions. This is not verifiable or calculable, so it is not included.
The People in Need figure includes all Afghan refugees- 3,100,000 million undocumented Afghans and 627,000 registered Afghan refugees, and 7,50000 card holders.

Level 1 includes all people living in the three regions hosting the majority of refugees. Approximately 55% of refugees live in the provinces of Tehran, Isfahan, and Khorasan Razavi. Since most refugees and undocumented Afghans live in urban areas of Iran (96%), it is difficult to assume that all Iranians are exposed, for the purpose of the Severity Index, this crisis is limited in geographic scope to these most affected areas.

There is no one considered to be in Level 2, because everyone who is affected (undocumented Afghans and Documented Afghan refugees in the country) is also assumed to be in need. Thus all Afghan refugees are considered to be at least at in moderate humanitarian condition.

Level 3 includes registered Afghan refugees and Card Holders. There is a government response as well as UNHCR and limited NGO response to the refugees in the country. There are provisions to provide easier access to healthcare and education for refugees, alleviating the severity of some needs. However, they are still in need, particularly in terms of shelter, livelihood, and WASH support. They are considered to be in moderate need.

Undocumented Afghans are considered to be on Level 4. This is because undocumented Afghans have extremely limited access to healthcare, economic opportunity, and education, and are constantly under threat of forced deportation from Iranian authorities. The dispersal of this population in urban areas means there is a limited coordinated response to their needs, putting them in severe humanitarian need.
There is no information of any afghan refugee facing extreme humanitarian condition.

As per UNICEF, Sri Lanka's economy saw some stabilisation after the IMF debt restructuring agreement on 20 March 2023. However, many vulnerable families faced food insecurity and nutrition challenges, loss of livelihoods, and rising protection concerns as they continue to depend on negative coping mechanisms. So, people living in poverty are considered as affected. When the crisis was opened, the entire population was considered affected by the crisis.

Flood-affected people are not added to this figure to avoid double counting as their profile indicate that they were already affected by the socio-economic crisis.

Total number of PIN according to the revised HNP 2022 was 7 million. There is currently no PIN figure. So, the percentage of people facing moderate food insecurity is considered to be the PIN figure which is 24% of the total population (5.28 million people).  Flood-affected people are not added to this figure to avoid double counting as their profile indicate that they were already affected by the socio-economic crisis.

The DTM has identified a total of 31,481 IDPs (6,054 IDP households) across 29 sites in Hela, Southern Highlands, Enga, Western Highlands, Jiwaka and Eastern Highlands provinces. Therefore, the IDP population has increased by 56.59% since 22 August 2022. Although the figure is old, media reports seem to indicate the violence and conflict are still resulting in displacement but the exact figure of the number of IDPs is unknown. So, the IOM data is still used for the displacement figure.

The number of displaced people in considered as the number of people in need.  Displaced people tend to flee to other communities in and outside the respective provinces or to neighbouring mountains.They usually face the following isues:
- Lack of resources of the displaced.
- General lack of coping capacity and high vulnerability
- Displacement sites such as churches were struggling to meet the basic needs and health care for the displaced.
- Humanitarian access to displaced is very low.
- Being displaced for a long term.

Justification:
The total pastureland is considered to be affected by the Dzud.The data on exact area affected is unavailable.

The total pastureland was chosen for landmass affected as the affected population are herder households. As at 20 December 2023, 90% of the country was at high or extreme dzud risk. As at 20 February 2024, more thab 80% of the country are facing dzud or near dzud conditions.

Source and Date: OCHA and UNCT Mongolia 25/03/2024; National Statistics Office of Mongolia 2020
Justification:
According to the OCHA Dzud Response Plan, the number of herder households being directly impacted by the dzud is 119,600 and number of herder households living in areas experiencing near-dzud condition 31,740. Therefore, total affected = 119,600 + 31,740 = 151,340 households.

Total population affected = 151,340 x 3.6 (average household size) = 544,824
No displacement reported due to the Dzud.
No injuries reported due to the Dzud.

Number of fatalities in affected areas in the last 6 months due to Dzud or related environmental conditions. Six months previous to the month the severity index (SI) is calculated are considered. For example, for the January 2023 version of SI, months considered will be July 2022 to December 2022.

Total number of fatalities for all the crises for the last 6 months. Six months previous to the month the severity index (SI) is calculated are considered. For example, for January 2023 version of SI, months considered will be July 2022 to December 2022.
Number of people in need estimated by OCHA in the Dzud Response Plan.

Justification: Level 1 figure is calculated based on the ACAPS methodology using the equation: Level 1 = exposed population - affected population. Exposed population is the number of people who belong to herder households and affected population population is the number of people being directly impacted by the Dzud and people living in areas experiencing near-dzud condition.

Source and Date: OCHA and UNCT Mongolia 25/03/2024; National Statistics Office of Mongolia 2020
Justification: Level 2 figure is calculated based on the ACAPS methodology using the equation: Level 2 = affected population - people in need. Affected population is the number of people being directly impacted by the Dzud and people living in areas experiencing near-dzud condition.

Level 3 figure is calculated based on the ACAPS methodology using the equation: Level 2 = affected population - people in need: Level 3 = people in need - population in level 4.

Between 1 January and 24 December, over 30,386(9)** measles** cases, including 233 deaths (0.77 per cent) were reported across Ethiopia, mainly from the five regions of SWEP (36 per cent), Oromia (23 per cent), Amhara (16 per cent) and Somali (10 per cent) representing 89 per cent of the cases. With regards to cholera, the outbreak continues to affect 11 regions with close to 29,380 cases, including 421 deathsand a cumulative case fatality rate (CFR) of 1.43 per cent between January and 23 December 2023, according to the Ethiopian Public Health Institute.  We sum Measles and Cholera cases to have an approximation of the total number of illness cases reported (excluding malaria which is expressed in terms of million cases; 3.7 million(8)** cases** between 1 January and 17 December this year.). In TOTAL we have 30,386 +  29,380 = 59766

The Amhara Public Health Institute (APHI), a total of 506,058 malaria cases with 13 deaths have been reported between 9 July - 11 November. The Upsurge of cholera outbreaks in North Wello and Wag Hamra zones have been reported with over 500 cases in November 2023.

The Escalation of the Nagorno-Karabakh (NK) conflict in 2023 resulted in the influx of up to 115183 people from the NK to Armenia (as of 07 February 2024), and 26,725 displaced people are living in a refugee-like situation in Armenia were already living in Armenia before 2023 war that were sheltering with host families, collective shelters, and rented accommodation across 11 provinces.
The figure represents the total population of ethnic Armenians in NK minus the number of people displaced from NK to Armenia as of 07 February 2024.

Total number of crisis-related fatalities in the last 6 months. Six months previous to the month the severity index (SI) is calculated are considered. For example, for the January 2023 version of SI, months considered will be July 2022 to December 2022.

The total population of Sudan represents the total population living in Sudan including refugees and excluding the number of Sudanese who left the country since 15 April 2023 because of the conflict that erupted between the SAF and RSF (2 million people displaced).
The number represents all the area of Sudan because the whole country is impacted by the complex crisis.

The total population of Sudan is exposed to the complex crisis. All states of Sudan have either been directly exposed by the conflict between the RSF and SAF or indirectly by receiving displaced people from other states. Additionally, all of Sudan is impacted by food insecurity and the socioeconomic impacts of the ongoing conflict.

The total population of Sudan is considered affected by the complex crisis. All states of Sudan have either been directly affected by the conflict between the RSF and SAF or indirectly by receiving displaced people from other states. Additionally, all of Sudan is impacted by food insecurity and the socioeconomic impacts of the ongoing conflict.

Inside Sudan: the number includes IDPs within Sudan (8,636,591) as of 7 April 2024 + Returnees in Sudan as of May 2023 (1.3 million) + Outside Sudan: Sudanese refugees in Chad as of 7 April 2024 (571,815) + Sudanese refugees in South Sudan as of 7 April 2024 (135,085) + Sudanese refugees in Egypt as of 14 March 2024 (500,000) + Sudanese refugees in Ethiopia as of 7 April 2024 (33,389) + Sudanese refugees in CAR as of 17 March 2024 (23,286). The number of refugees from other nationalities is not considered here, as the primary cause of their displacement is not the complex crisis in Sudan.
Fatalities between 15 October 2023 to 15 April 2024 across Sudan. The figure is reliable and seems consistent with other secondary sources and media articles.
Fatalities between 15 October 2023 to 15 April 2024 across Sudan. The figure is reliable and seems consistent with other secondary sources and media articles.

Source and Date: OCHA 21/12/2023 ; OCHA JIAF accessed 15/04/2024 ; OCHA HDX accessed 15/04/2024
Justification: The number of people in need in Sudan based on OCHA's HNRP 2024. The number of people estimated to need humanitarian assistance across the country in 2023 has jumped from 15.8 million to 24.7 million following the clashes that erupted between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in multiple areas of Sudan on 15 April 2023. Drivers of the crisis include political instability following the military takeover on 25 October 2021 and the onset of conflict on 15 April 2023, a socioeconomic crisis characterised by high inflation rates and currency depreciation, and food insecurity affecting the majority of the population, projected to further deteriorate.

Source and Date: OCHA 21/12/2023 ; OCHA JIAF accessed 15/04/2024 ; OCHA HDX accessed 15/04/2024
Justification: According to INFORM severity index methodology, the number of people facing Minimal humanitarian conditions or in Level 1= People exposed - People affected. Since the whole population is exposed and affected by the complex crisis in Sudan, there are no people in minimal humanitarian conditions.

Source and Date: OCHA 21/12/2023 ; OCHA JIAF accessed 15/04/2024 ; OCHA HDX accessed 15/04/2024
Justification: According to the INFORM severity index methodology, people facing stressed humanitarian conditions or Level 2 = People affected - People in Need (PIN). The whole population is affected by the complex crisis in Sudan, and the People in Need figure is provided by OCHA's HNRP 2024.

Source and Date: OCHA 21/12/2023 ; OCHA JIAF accessed 15/04/2024 ; OCHA HDX accessed 15/04/2024
Justification: The severity of needs is calculated by cross-checking the number of PiN in each admin 2 provided by the HNRP data on OCHA HDX (last updated on 22 December 2023) with the admin 2 with the highest severity according to OCHA JIAF dashboard. For example, the number of people in need in Al Hasahisa, Aj Jazirah state is 269,705 according to OCHA's HNRP 2024. Al Hasahisa's severity is assigned as 3 according to JIAF dashboard. The number of people facing moderate humanitarian conditions or in Level 3 is the total of the PiN of admin 2 that are assigned as 3 by JIAF (10,546,855 people). Compared to OCHA's HRP (May 2023), the total number of people in level 5 was 10,485,000 people. The reliability of this data point is set to low as the calculation used to obtain the number comes from ACAPS interpretation of JIAF figures of severity-per-analysis unit, which does not consider the diversity of severity of needs within the same unit.

Source and Date: OCHA 21/12/2023 ; OCHA JIAF accessed 15/04/2024 ; OCHA HDX accessed 15/04/2024
Justification: The severity of needs is calculated by cross-checking the number of PiN in each admin 2 provided by the HNRP data on OCHA HDX (last updated on 22 December 2023) with the admin 2 with the highest severity according to OCHA JIAF dashboard. For example, the number of people in need in Al Kamlin, Aj Jazirah state is 291,484 according to OCHA's HNRP 2024. Al Kamlin's severity is assigned as 4 according to JIAF dashboard. The number of people facing severe humanitarian conditions or in Level 4 is the total of the PiN of admin 2 that are assigned as 4 by JIAF (10,651,621 people). Compared to OCHA's HRP (May 2023), the total number of people in level 5 was 8,970,000 people. There is an increase in the number of people in Level 4 and a decrease in the number of people in Level 5, while the overall PiN is almost the same between the HRP in 2023 and the HNRP in 2024. The reliability of this data point is set to low as the calculation used to obtain the number comes from ACAPS interpretation of JIAF figures of severity-per-analysis unit, which does not consider the diversity of severity of needs within the same unit

Source and Date: OCHA 21/12/2023 ; OCHA JIAF accessed 15/04/2024 ; OCHA HDX accessed 15/04/2024
Justification: The severity of needs is calculated by cross-checking the number of PiN in each admin 2 provided by the HNRP data on OCHA HDX (last updated on 22 December 2023) with the admin 2 with the highest severity according to JIAF dashboard. For example, the number of people in need in Um Durman, Khartoum is 172,007 according to OCHA's HNRP 2024. Um Durman's severity is assigned as 5 according to JIAF dashboard. The number of people facing extreme humanitarian conditions or in Level 5 is the total of the PiN of admin 2 that are assigned as 5 by JIAF (3,587,894 people). In the OCHA HNO 2023, the totoal number of people in level 5 was 5,228,000 people. There is an increase in the number of people in Level 4 and a decrease in the number of people in Level 5, while the overall PiN is almost the same between the HRP in 2023 and the HNRP in 2024.

The total population of Sudan represents the total population inside Sudan including refugees and excluding the number of Sudanese who left the country since 15 April 2023 because of the conflict that erupted between the SAF and RSF (2 million people)
Refugees are hosted in all states in Sudan. The total landmass of the country is considered.
The whole country is exposed to the refugee crisis as all states hosts refugees who are also being impacted by the ongoing conflict and being displaced again.

People living in the states that host over 100K refugees (Khartoum, White Nile, and Kassala) are considered affected. As Sudan's population is at least 49 million and the number of refugees is 900,000, we only considered the three states hosting the largest number of refugees to be affected. They also host more than 100,000 refugees.
Refugees and Asylum-seekers in Sudan (961,993) as of 31 Dec 2023. The majority of them are from South Sudan.
Fatalities between 15 October 2023 to 15 April 2024 related to refugees. The refugees were targeted and killed by armed groups.
Fatalities between 15 October 2023 to 15 April 2024 across Sudan. The figure is reliable and seems consistent with other secondary sources and media articles.
All the refugees in Sudan are considered to be in need as they are affected by their displacement status and the complex crisis impacting Sudan.

According to INFORM severity index methodology, the number of people facing Minimal humanitarian conditions or in Level 1= People exposed - People affected. The people exposed is the total population, as all states in Sudan hosts refugees. The people affected are the total population of the three states hosting the largest number of refugees (more than 100,000 refugee).

According to the INFORM severity index methodology, people facing stressed humanitarian conditions or Level 2 = People affected - People in Need (PIN). The people affected are the total population of the three states hosting the largest number of refugees (more than 100,000 refugee). The PiN figure is the total refugee population in Sudan  as they are affected by their displacement status and the complex crisis impacting Sudan.

Over 30000 malaria cases have been reported from the period July-December 2023 as published by OCHA 14/03/2024. Approximately 458,700 children under the age of five are likely to suffer acute malnutrition. Among them, over 121,000 children are expected to suffer from Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) and nearly 338,000 children are expected to experience Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM). In the Grand Sud Est region, an estimated 196,451 cases are projected, with 57,973 children in SAM and 138,478 children in MAM. In total we add the 30,000 malaria cases to that of malnutrition 196,451 = 226,451

Justification: There has been a change in method for this indicator. We used the INFORM severity methodology to find level 1=Exposed (minus) Affected. The total population of Libya in 2024, including incoming migrants, refugees, and asylum seekers.
The figure represents the total landmass of Libya

The whole population is exposed to the complex crisis, drivern by conflict, displacement, socio-political issues, and natural hazards. Libya has been in a civil war since 2011 following the Arab Spring uprising, with full-scale armed clashes between supporters of former leader Muammar Gaddafi and opposing armed groups. This has resulted in political instability, protracted violence, the emergence of various armed groups looking to control Libya, damage to critical infrastructure, and severe disruptions to the country's oil production. On 10 September 2023, Storm Daniel hit northeastern Libya, resulting in the collapse of two dams in Derna district and needs for more than 884,000 people, mostly WASH, health, food, and livelihood. Libya is a transit country for migrants and asylum seekers, mostly Sub-Saharan Africans aiming to reach Europe.

The whole population is considered affected at different degrees by the complex crisis as it impacts all states in Libya. The complex crisis is drivern by conflict, displacement, socio-political issues, and natural hazards. Libya has been in a civil war since 2011 following the Arab Spring uprising, with full-scale armed clashes between supporters of former leader Muammar Gaddafi and opposing armed groups. This has resulted in political instability, protracted violence, the emergence of various armed groups looking to control Libya, damage to critical infrastructure, and severe disruptions to the country's oil production. On 10 September 2023, Storm Daniel hit northeastern Libya, resulting in the collapse of two dams in Derna district and needs for more than 884,000 people, mostly WASH, health, food, and livelihood. Libya is a transit country for migrants and asylum seekers, mostly Sub-Saharan Africans aiming to reach Europe.

The figure represents the total IDPs in Libya as of 31 Aug 2023 (125,802) + Total IDP returnees in Libya as of 31 August 2023 (705,426) + People displaced following storm Daniel and the floods as at November 2023 (44,800). The numbers of refugees, asylum seekers, and migrants in Libya are not included as the driver of their displacement is not the complex crisis in Libya.

The figure includes the total fatalities in the country between 15 October 2023 to 15 April 2024 (26 people) + the fatalities on the Central and Western Mediterranean migration route between 15 October 2023 to 15 April 2024 (913 people)

The updated PiN figure includes the number of people in need identified following storm Daniel and the floods in the affected areas of Al Jabal Al Akhdar, Almarj, Benghazi, Derna, and Tobruk (884,479 people) and the number of PiN from the latest HNO (2023) for the remaining areas in Libya (280,300 people). The complex crisis in Libya is drivern by conflict, displacement, socio-political issues, and natural hazards.

According to INFORM severity index methodology, the number of people facing Minimal humanitarian conditions or in Level 1= People exposed - People affected. Since the whole population is exposed and affected by the complex crisis in Libya, there are no people in minimal humanitarian conditions.

According to the INFORM severity index methodology, people facing stressed humanitarian conditions or Level 2 = People affected - People in Need (PIN). The whole population is affected by the complex crisis in Libya, and the People in Need figure includes the number of people in need identified following storm Daniel and the floods in the affected areas of Al Jabal Al Akhdar, Almarj, Benghazi, Derna, and Tobruk (884,479 people) and the number of PiN from the latest HNO (2023) for the remaining areas in Libya (280,300 people).

The updated PiN figure includes the number of people in need identified following storm Daniel and the floods in the affected areas of Al Jabal Al Akhdar, Almarj, Benghazi, Derna, and Tobruk (884,479 people) and the number of PiN from the latest HNO (2023) for the remaining areas in Libya (280,300 people), excluding the number of refugees, migrants, asylum seekers, and the people displaced following storm Daniel as they are considered to face severe humanitarian conditions and put in Level 4. The complex crisis in Libya is driven by conflict, displacement, socio-political issues, and natural hazards. Since there is no breakdown of the severity of needs available and to avoid double counting, all the people in need are considered to be facing moderate humanitarian conditions.

The refugees, asylum seeker, and migrants in Libya, in addition to the people who were displaced following storm Daniel, are considered to have more needs and face severe humanitarian conditions. The registered refugees and asylum-seekers in Libya as of 1 April 2024  are 62,527 people. The number of migrants in Libya during the period October–December 2023  are 706,369 people. The people displaced following storm Daniel and the floods as at November 2023 are 44,800 people. Libya is a transit country for migrants and asylum seekers, mostly Sub-Saharan Africans, aiming to reach Europe. The lack of legal status and, for many, the lack of recognition of their refugee status expose them to severe protection violations, especially in the official and unofficial detention centres nationwide. On 10 September 2023, Storm Daniel hit northeastern Libya, resulting in the collapse of two dams in Derna district and needs, mostly WASH, health, food, and livelihood. Besides severely damaging infrastructure, the crisis led to water contamination, increasing the risk of disease outbreaks.
There are no people considered facing extreme humanitarian conditions. This has also been cross-checked with the Libya 2023 HNO.

Crisis: Storm Daniel and floods in Libya
Justification: While the people living in the impacted governorates are considered all exposed to the crisis, they are not all affected. Not everyone within the exposed population have experienced the full impact of the crisis equally. Some areas were heavily inundated or directly impacted, such as Derna, while others experienced less severe consequences. The people affected are considered the same as the people in need of humanitarian assistance, since they have directly experienced the consequences of the crisis.

According to the 2024 HNO/HNRP, the total number of people in need in northern Mozambique, which is conflict-affected, is 1.7M. The people in level 3 were estimated by subtracting people in level 4 (1,160,000) in the conflict affected admin2 levels from the PIN in conflict affected provinces (1.7M) to get 540,000. 
We included level 1,2 and 3 from the HNO 2024 data on HDX to get the people we used in level 3. 

For the natural disaster/2024 Rainy and cyclone season, the people in level 3 were estimated by subtracting people in level 4 in natural disaster crisis in admin2 levels from the PIN in  natural disaster crisis provinces (546,000). We included level 1,2 and 3 from the HDX data to get the people we used in level 3.

Levels 1 and 2 were computed using INFORM severity methodology. Level 3 and above are equal to people in need. 

As for level 4, HDX data from the HNO 2024 was used to extract number of people in need in level 4. 
Nine districts were classified under HNO 2024 as level 4; therefore, we worked with the severity of people in level 4 in admin2 (who are mostly in Cabo Delgado) with the corresponding number of people with intersectoral needs (instead of people in need per individual sector, to avoid double counting and an overlap). We summed up people in need (intersectoral) per admin level 4 for the conflict crisis, which produced 1,159,188.87 that we rounded up to 1,160,000. We did the same for natural disaster in 2024 (rainy and cyclone season), and rounded up 7,952.4  to 8,000. Then, we summed the two, which is 1,168,000 in total (total number of people in level 4 for the two crises - crisis aggregation in the INFORM SI).

The figure is the total population of Lebanon according to OCHA, including refugees, migrants, and asylum seekers.

The total population is exposed to the socio-economic crisis, including the Syrian refugees. Since at least 2019, mounting public debt, high fiscal deficit, and political instability have been driving the socioeconomic crisis in the country, resulting in the devaluation of the Lebanese pound, increased unemployment and multidimensional poverty, business closures, inflation, limited access to foreign exchange and imports, and decreased foreign remittances.
The total population is affected by the socio-economic crisis, including the Syrian refugees.

There are no information indicating that people have been displaced due to the socio-economic crisis in Lebanon. However, the people displaced due to the conflict between Hezbollah and Israel since 8 October are considered here, as displacement and conflict contributes to worsening the economic and social situation in Lebanon.

About 974 people are injured between 08 October 2023 and 02 April 2024 because of Israeli airstrikes on southern Lebanon. The figure is kept as an info gap because for the time being, this crisis is related to the socio-economic conditions in Lebanon.

The figure represents the number of fatalities  across Lebanon in the period between 01 October 2023 and 05 April 2024. This includes fatalities due to the conflict between Hezbollah and Israel, as it shows an indication of the severity of the conflict and its overall impact on the socio-economic situation in Lebanon, in terms of access to services and social tensions.

The figure represents the number of fatalities  across Lebanon in the period between 01 October 2023 and 05 April 2024. This includes fatalities due to the conflict between Hezbollah and Israel, as it shows an indication of the severity of the conflict and its overall impact on the socio-economic situation in Lebanon, in terms of access to services and social tensions.
The figure represents the number of PIN in Lebanon, including Displaced Syrians, Palestinian Refugees from Syria (PRS), Migrants,Vulnerable Lebanese and Palestine Refugees in Lebanon (PRL).

According to the INFORM Severity Index methodology, Level 1 = People exposed – People affected. Both are considered the total population. Since at least 2019, mounting public debt, high fiscal deficit, and political instability have been driving the socioeconomic crisis in the country, resulting in the devaluation of the Lebanese pound, increased unemployment and multidimensional poverty, business closures, inflation, limited access to foreign exchange and imports, and decreased foreign remittances.

According to the INFORM Severity Index methodology, Level 2 = People affected – PiN. The people affected are considered to be the total population, and the PiN is provided by OCHA and it represents the number of PIN in Lebanon, including Displaced Syrians, Palestinian Refugees from Syria (PRS), Migrants,Vulnerable Lebanese and Palestine Refugees in Lebanon (PRL).

There is no breakdown of the severity of needs provided by the 3RP Regional Strategic Overview or a new updated PiN provided by OCHA. An IPC analysis is available, but food security needs are not the highest in Lebanon. The highest reported needs by sector according to OCHA are social stability, health, and energy. Though the IPC analysis provides a good breakdown of the food security needs in the projected period of April – September 2024, ACAPS decided not to include it in the severity index breakdown as it is not indicative of the people's most reported needs. The whole PiN available will be considered in Level 3.

The Syrian crisis involves the whole country, and thus the whole population of Lebanon is exposed. The Lebanese Government estimates that around 1.5 million Syrian refugees reside in Lebanon, besides around 489,300 Palestinian refugees and around 11,600 refugees of other nationalities. With the Lebanese population of 5.3 million, these figures make Lebanon the country with the biggest refugee-to-resident population ratio. Almost the entire Syrian population in Lebanon lives on an income that does not cover basic needs.

Justification: Afghanistan’s population is estimated to pass the 44.5 million in 2024 according to OCHA's estimates.

Conflict and natural disasters contributed to humanitarian needs in all provinces and districts in Afghanistan. Although certain areas and populations are considered to be more severely affected, it is assumed that the entire country is experiencing a humanitarian crisis to a certain extent.

While conflict affects the entire country and is the primary driver of needs in Afghanistan, the country is also severely impacted by natural hazards such as drought, flooding, and the earthquake. Needs are also driven by the sociopolitical impacts of years of conflict. The entire country and therefore the entire population is exposed to various crises, though to different degrees.

Given the complexity and protracted nature of the conflict and natural hazards driving needs across the country, according to the revised HRP, all districts of the country experienced either severe, extreme, or catastrophic multisectoral needs. Therefore, we are excluding the previous number of people affected from the HNO and considering that the entire population is impacted by various crises.

Source and Date: OCHA accessed 18/04/2024; IOM accessed on 18/04/2024; UNHCR accessed 18/04/2024
Justification: Displacement in Afghanistan is a complex issue, compounded by both natural disasters and conflict. Current estimates suggest a total of approximately 23 million individuals displaced, including internally displaced persons (IDPs) numbering around 4.1 million, returnees totalling 11 million, and refugees who have fled outside Afghanistan (3 million in Pakistan, 4.5 million in Iran, 13,020 in Uzbekistan and 8,451 in Tajikistan). Tracking refugees is challenging due to recurring displacement, particularly along border regions with Pakistan and Iran, where unofficial crossings are common. To avoid double counting and as there is no historical tracking of their number, the number of Afghans who are coming back from neighbouring countries on daily basis are not included.

The figure is the total PIN according to the latest HRP (for 2024) published in December 2023. The recent bans on Afghan women working for INGOs and the UN have added yet another layer of complexity to aid provision. The people in need of humanitarian assistance because of the Herat earthquake are already included in OCHA's HRP, therefore the number will not be added to that of PIN in the complex crisis INFORM severity index calculations to avoid duplication. Food needs are reported to be the most priority need, with 91% of people in rural areas and 83% of people in urban areas indicating food as their primary need. However, the latest IPC analysis was not considered by ACAPS as alternative source to represent the PiN in the INFORM severity index as it only considers food needs. Other needs such as health, livelihoods, clean drinking water, and protection are also high in Afghanistan. The number of people projected to be facing Crisis food insecurity levels or worse (IPC Phase 3 and above) by March 2024 are 15.8 million people, with 3.5 million people in Phase 4.

According to INFORM severity index methodology, the number of people facing Minimal humanitarian conditions or in Level 1= People exposed - People affected. Since the whole population is exposed and affected by the complex crisis in Afghanistan, there are no people facing minimal humanitarian conditions.

According to the INFORM severity index methodology, people facing stressed humanitarian conditions or Level 2 = People affected - People in Need (PIN). The whole population is affected by the complex crisis in Afghanistan, and the People in Need figure is provided by OCHA's HNRP 2024.

As per OCHA's 2024 HRP, the people in need of humanitarian assistance in 2024 are 23.7 million. The number of people in Levels 3, 4, and 5 is calculated based on the percentages of the PiN figure in the 2023 HNO. According to the 2023 HNO, about 48,3% of the people in need were facing moderate humanitarian conditions (Level 3) and 51,8% of the people in need were facing severe humanitarian conditions (Level 4), and none were considered to be facing extereme humanitarian conditions. Following on these percentages and the updated PiN figure of OCHA's 2024 HRP, 48,3% of the PiN is 11,447,100 people facing moderate humanitarian conditions (Level 3), and 51,8% of the PiN is about 12,276,600 people facing severe humanitarian conditions (Level 4). There are no people facing extereme humanitarian conditions. Food needs are reported to be a priority, with 91% of people in rural areas and 83% of people in urban areas indicating food as their primary need. However, the latest IPC analysis was not considered by ACAPS as alternative source to represent the PiN in the INFORM severity index as it only considers food needs. Other needs such as health, livelihoods, clean drinking water, and protection are also high in Afghanistan. The number of people projected to be facing Crisis food insecurity levels or worse (IPC Phase 3 and above) by March 2024 are 15.8 million people, with 3.5 million people in Phase 4

The total landmass of Herat province that has been affected by the earthquake that happened in October 2023.

The figure is the total population of Herat province according to OCHA's HNO 2023. All people in that province are considered exposed to the earthquake that happened in October 2023. More than 30,000 homes were severely damaged or destroyed.
1.6 million people in Herat Province have been affected by the earthquakes between 7 and 15 October 2023.  More than 30,000 homes were severely damaged or destroyed.
The Number of people displaced by the specific crisis is not available.
The number of people in need according to OCHA's revised response plan for the earthquake.

The whole population of Herat province is considered to be exposed to the impact of earthquakes, among those 1.6 million have been affected. Thus the rest 1.9 million people who are not affected, but still exposed to the impact of erathquake are considered to have minimal humanitarian condition-Level 1.

The people affected is 1.6 million where 275,000 people are in urgent need, therefore people in stressed humanitarian conditions are considered 1.3 million (people affected minus people in urgent need).

The response plan does not provide a clear breakdown of the severity of needs, but 43,400 people have been directly impacted by the earthquakes. Therefore those 43,400 people are considered to be more severely affected/experiencing more severe humanitarian conditions and put at Severe humanitarian conditions - Level 4. All the rest of people in need are considered in Level 3 as per the INFORM severity index methodology (PIN for the Hearthquake - Level 4 (directly impacted) = Level 3; 275.000-43.4000=231.600)

The revised response plan does not provide a clear breakdown of humanitarian condition of the people in need. But according to OCHA's response plan (published in October) 43,400 people were directly impacted by the earthquakes. Therefore, those 43,400 people are considered to be facing more humanitarian conditions/higher needs and put at Severe humanitarian conditions - Level 4. The remaining people in need (PIN - directly impacted) are considered in Level 3.
It is considered zero as there is no indication that people are facing Extreme humanitarian conditions - Level 5 because of the earthquakes.

Total population of South Sudan according to the HNO 2024.The total population figures from the HNO were preferred to accurately calculate level 1-5 PIN as given in the HNO 2023 and avoid discrepancies.
Total landmass of South Sudan. The crisis is experienced in almost all parts of the country hence the total area used.

South Sudan continues to grapple with pervasive insecurity, significant internal displacement, and a rise in refugees fleeing to neighboring countries amidst worsening food security and intercommunal violence. The influx of refugees into South Sudan since April 2023 exacerbates the situation, leaving the entire population vulnerable to the crisis
Since the entire country is exposed to the complex crisis, the entire population is considered affected

South Sudan continues to grapple with pervasive insecurity, significant internal displacement, and a rise in refugees fleeing to neighboring countries amidst worsening food security and intercommunal violence. The influx of refugees into South Sudan since April 2023 exacerbates the situation, leaving the entire population vulnerable to the crisis. Since this is a complex protracted crisis, the whole country is affected  by the crisis to a certain extent.

The number of displaced people includes total number of IDPs,  returning refugees  and outgoing South Sudanese refugees in other countries . While the number of returnees seems high, the dynamics of displacements and returns in South Sudan are complex. Some movements labelled as "returns" actually constitute back and forth movements which happen over the course of a person's lifetime.
Although some people have been injured, there is no reliable information on the cumilative figures

HNRP 2024 for PIN and severity levels from 2023 HNO as percentages of PIN were taken. For Level 4 (Severe conditions)  percentage for HNO 2023 was used i.e level 4 = 84%*8,546,986M (HNRP 2024). This approach was used as the HNRP 2024 did not have the different severity levels.

HNRP 2024 for PIN and severity levels from 2023 HNO as percentages of PIN were taken. For Level 5 (Extreme conditions)  percentage for HNO 2023 was used i.e level 5 = 1%*8,546,986M (HNRP 2024). This approach was used as the HNRP 2024 did not have the different severity levels.

The entire population of Somalia is exposed to the complex crisis affecting every state. Conflicts, inter-communal tensions, and floods directly impact regions, leading to the displacement of people who seek refuge across state lines. Additionally, the country is struggling with severe food insecurity, exacerbated by ongoing conflicts, disease outbreaks, and economic challenges.

The total population of the Republic of Burkina Faso summarizes the total population of the country's 13 regions. It comprised of persons of all age groups and gender especially persons affected by population movement due to the complex crisis such as refugees, asylum seekers, internally displaced people, returnees and host communities.
The complex crisis in Burkina Faso affects the whole country, therefore the total landmass of the country is considered.

People exposed to the complex crisis in Burkina Faso include; host communities, refugees, asylum seekers, IDPs, and returnees situated in the 13 regions of the country. Burkina Faso is experiencing insecurity at the national level which makes the entire population exposed to armed group attacks as presented by the Humanitarian Response Plan According to the inform severity index methodology note published by the Joint Research Centre, this figure also represents the total of the severity breakdown from level 1 to 5 (Level 1+2+3+4+5).

Affected people in the crisis-affected area include internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, asylum seekers and outgoing migrants in the neighbouring countries. According to the Inform Severity index methodology note published by the Joint Research Centre, people affected represents the total figure of 4 severity levels (Level 2+3+4+5). The total # of people affected is 6,293,939.
People in need of humanitarian assistance in the sectors of education, food security, WASH, shelter, general protection, livelihood, and health, in the 13 regions of Burkina Faso.

The level 1 humanitarian condition as outlined by the inform severity index methodology note, is obtained through a difference between people exposed and people affected (people exposed - people affected) which will provide the total of 17,006,061 people. Hence, in the case of BFA002, it corresponds to total population (people exposed) - PIN levels 2+3+4+5 from latest HNO/HNRP 2024 (people affected).
Since all the people affected are considered to be in need, they are placed in the PIN level indicators.

The number of people in moderate humanitarian conditions (Level 3) was obtained through the application of the percentages extrapolated from the severity of needs distribution used in the HNO 2023. They represent 55.5% of the number of the total PIN.

The number of people in severe humanitarian conditions (Level 4) was obtained through the application of the percentages extrapolated from the severity of needs distribution used in the HNO 2023. They represent 41.9% of the number of the total PIN.

The number of people in extreme humanitarian conditions (Level 5) was obtained through the application of the percentages extrapolated from the severity of needs distribution used in the HNO 2023. They represent 1.9% of the total PIN figure.

The total population of the Central African Republic was obtained from the Humanitarian Needs Overview of 2024. This figure summarizes the total population of the 17 departments of the Central African Republic. It comprised of persons of all age groups and gender especially persons affected by population movement due to the complex crisis such as; refugees, asylum seekers, internally displaced people, returnees and host communties.

The total square kilometre of the Central African Republic was gotten from the 2021 statistics of the World Bank. This figure summarizes the landmass affected by the complex crisis of the 17 departments of the Central African Republic.

People exposed to the complex crisis in the Central African Republic include; host communities, refugees, asylum seekers, IDPs, and returnees situated in the 17 departments of the Central African Republic. This country is experiencing a complex crisis at the national level which makes the entire population exposed to armed group attacks as presented by the 2024 HNO. According to the inform severity index methodology note published by the Joint Research Centre, this figure also represents the total of the severity breakdown from level 1 to 5 (Level 1+2+3+4+5).

People affected by the complex crisis in the Central African Republic include; host communities, refugees, asylum seekers, IDPs, and returnees situated in the 17 departments of the Central African Republic. According to the inform severity index methodology note published by the Joint Research Centre, people affected represents the total figure of 4 severity levels (Level 2+3+4+5). As seen in the calcualtion process of the severity level from 2 to 5, people affected will give total of 2,800,000 persons.

N. of people in need of assistance in the following sectors: education, food security, WASH, shelter, GBV, general protection, child protection, nutrition and health, in the 17 departments of the Central African Republic. The number was taken from the latest HNRP/HNO 2024.

Minimal humanitarian conditions affected by persons living in the 17 departments (72 sub-departments) of the Central African Republic. The level 1 humanitarian condition as outlined by the inform severity index methodology note, is obtained through a difference between people exposed and people affected (people exposed - people affected) which will provide the total of 3,300,000 peoples.

Stressed humanitarian conditions are affected persons living in 06 out of 72 sub-departments of the Central African Republic. The level 2 humanitarian condition as outlined by the inform severity index methodology note, is obtained through a difference between people affected and people in need (people affected - PIN) which will provide the total of 0 people since the same number of persons are affected by the insecurity crisis in the Central African Republic.

Moderate humanitarian conditions affect people living in 56 out of 72 sub-departments of the Central African Republic. Level 3 represents the total of  the total population of those sub-departments. Hence, 2,500,000 persons are affected by the insecurity crisis in the Central African Republic asestimated usng latest data from the HNO/HNRP 2024.

The number of people in level 4 are living in 10 out of 72 sub-departments of the Central African Republic. The sub-departments affected include Bambou, Obo, Zémio, Bakouma, Zangba, Ouanda-Djallé, Birao, Kabo, Markounda and Ngaoundaye. Level 4 represents a summation of the PIN figures in those sub-departments, hence 313,000 people. This is an estimation from the latests HNO/HNRP 2024 data of area by severity.
No extreme humanitarian conditions were registered in the sub-departments of the Central African Republic as presented in the Humanitarian Needs Overview of 2024.

The total population of the Republic of Chad was obtained from the 2024 Humanitarian Needs Overview. This figure summarizes the total population of the 23 regions of Chad. It comprised of persons of all age groups and gender especially persons affected by population movement due to the complex crisis such as; refugees, asylum seekers, internally displaced people, returnees and host communties.

The total square kilometre of the Republic of Chad was gotten from the 2021 statistics of the World Bank. The whole Chad is exposed to the complex crisis drivers such insecurity, intercommunal violence and international displacement. Therefore, the whole landmass is included.

Security threats around Lake Chad, as well as military operations to contain these groups, have displaced civilians from their homes and disrupted livelihoods. Intercommunity violence over resources in the south also drives population displacement. Large and protracted refugee populations, mainly from the Central African Republic, Cameroon, Nigeria, and Sudan. These drivers alongside others made significant humanitarian needs across the country. Therefore, the whole population are considered exposed to the crisis.

Lacking information about the number of people who are affected by the crisis but not in need of humanitarian assistance. Therefore, it has been assumed the number of people in needs and equal to people affected.

The number of people in needs in Chad in 2024 according to the latest humanitarian needs overview. The number of people in needs are intersectoral. The needs are driven by widespread and continuous deteriorating security environment, protection threats, unmet humanitarian and development needs, and large displacement.
The number of people who are exposed to the crisis however not affected or in needs of urgent humanitarian assistance. There may be some needs but are not life-threatening.

Lacking of information about the number of people who are affected by the crisis but not in need of humanitarian assistance. Therefore, it has been assumed the number of people in needs and equal to people affected. Therefore stressed humanitarian level 2 is zero. 
The number of people who are affected by the crisis however not in needs of urgent humanitarian assistance. Needs are higher than level 1 but are still not life-threatening. The affected population can meet their needs by applying coping strategies.

To estimate people who are in moderate humanitarian conditions level 3, it was computed using the HNRP 2024 for PIN and severity levels from the area severity (page 15). The areas' severity is divided into 5 severity levels: minimal, stress, severe, extreme, and catastrophic based on 2024 HNRP.  
The whole PIN of areas with severity tagged as minimal, stress, and severe are matched with moderate humanitarian conditions level 3.

The regions included (minimal, stress, and severe HNRP); Tibesti, Ennedi Est, Ennedi Ouest, Batha, Guera, Salamat, Tandjile, Mandoul, Logone Occidental and N'Djamena.

People who are in severe humanitarian conditions level 4 have been computed using the HNRP 2024 for PIN and severity levels from the area severity (page 15). The areas' severity is divided into 5 severity levels: minimal, stress, severe, extreme, and catastrophic based on 2024 HNRP.  
The whole PIN of areas with severity tagged as extreme are matched with extreme humanitarian conditions level 4.

The regions included (extreme HNRP): Logone Oriental, Moyen-Chari, Sila, Wadi Fira, Ouaddai, Barh-El-Gazel, Kanem and Lac.

People who are in extreme humanitarian conditions level 5 have been computed using the HNRP 2024 for PIN and severity levels from the area severity (page 15). The areas' severity is divided into 5 severity levels: minimal, stress, severe, extreme, and catastrophic based on 2024 HNRP.  
The whole PIN of areas with severity tagged as catastrophic are matched with extreme humanitarian conditions level 5. However, no areas have been tagged in catastrophic situation in Chad.

The total population of the Republic of Mali is comprised of the 10 regions which regroups persons of all age groups and gender especially persons affected by population movement due to the complex crisis such as; refugees, asylum seekers, internally displaced people, returnees and host communties.

The total square kilometre of the Republic of Mali is was gotten from the 2021 statistics of the World Bank. This figure summarizes the landmass affected by the active complex crisis in the 10 regions of the Republic of Mali

People exposed to the complex crisis in the Republic of Mali include; host communities, refugees, asylum seekers, IDPs, and returnees situated in the 53 affected circles of the 10 regions of the of Repubic of Mali. This country is experiencing a complex crisis at the national level which makes the entire population exposed to armed groups attacks as presented by the 2024 HNO. According to the inform severity index methodology note published by the Joint Research Centre, this figure also represents the total of the severity breakdown from level 1 to level 5 (Level 1+2+3+4+5).

People affected by the complex crisis in the Republic of Mali include; host communities, refugees, asylum seekers, IDPs, and returnees situated in the 53 affected circles of the 10 regions of the of Repubic of Mali. According to the inform severity index methodology note published by the Joint Research Centre, people affected represents the total figure of 4 severity levels (Level 2+3+4+5). As seen in the calcualtion process of the severity level from 2 to 5, people affected will give total of 7,107,192 persons.

Persons in need of diverse assistance in the following sectors; education, food security, WASH, shelter, GBV, general protection, child protection, nutrition and health, in the 53 affected circles of the 10 regions of the of Repubic of Mali.

Minimal humanitarian conditions affected by persons living in the 10 regions of the Repubic of Mali as presented in the 2024 HNO. The level 1 humanitarian condition as outlined by the inform severity index methodology note, is obtained through a difference between people exposed to the complex crisis and people affected by the same complex crisis (people exposed - people affected) which will provide the total of 15,486,398 peoples.

Stressed humanitarian conditions are affected by persons living in 10 out of 53 affected circles of the 10 regions of the Repubic of Mali as presented in the 2024 HNO. The regions affected include; Bamako, Kayes (Kenieba, Bafoulabe, Kita, Yelimane), Koulikoro (Kangaba, Kati), and Sikasso (Bougouni, Kolondieba, Sikasso, Yanfolila). The level 2 humanitarian condition as outlined by the inform severity index methodology note, is obtained through a difference between people affected and people in need (people affected - PIN) which will provide the total of 0 people since the same number of persons are affected by the complex crisis in the Republic of Mali.

Moderate humanitarian conditions affected by persons living in 25 out of 53 affected circles of the 10 regions of the Repubic of Mali as presented in the 2024 HNO. The regions affected include;  Bamako, Kayes (Bafoulabe, Kayes, Kenieba, Kita, Yelimane), kidal (Abiebara, Kidal, Tessalit, Tin-Essako,), Koulikoro (Banamba, Dioila, Kangaba, Kati, Kolokani, Koulikoro), Menaka (Inekar, Menaka, Tidermene), Sikasso (Bougouni, Kadiolo, Kolondieba, Sikasso, Yanfolila) and Segou (Baroueli, Bla). Level 3 represents the total of 2,922,510 number of persons affected by the insecurity crisis in the Republic of Mali as presented in the Humanitarian Needs Overview of 2024.

Severe humanitarian conditions affected by persons living in the 16 out of 53 affected circles of the 10 regions of the Repubic of Mali as presented in the 2024 HNO. The regions affected include; Sikasso (Koutiala), Kayes (Diema), Koulikoro (Nara), Segou (San, Segou, Tominian), Mopti (Djenne, Mopti, Tenenko, Nioro, Douentza), Gao (Bourem) and Tombouctou (Dire, Niafounke, Goundam, Tombouctou). Level 4 represents the total of 2,481,957 number of persons affected by the insecurity crisis in the Republic of Mali as presented in the Humanitarian Needs Overview of 2024.

Extreme humanitarian conditions affected by persons living in the 10 out of 53 affected circles of the 10 regions of the Repubic of Mali as presented in the 2024 HNO. The regions affected include; Gao (Ansongo, Gao), Mopti (Youwarou, Bandiagara, Bankass, Koro), Menaka (Anderamboukane), Segou (Macina, Niono) and Tombouctou (Gourma-Rharous). Level 5 represents the total of 1,702,725 number of persons affected by the insecurity crisis in the Republic of Mali as presented in the Humanitarian Needs Overview of 2024.

The number of people in needs in Syria in 2024 increased from 15.3m to 16.7m according to the latest humanitarian needs overview. The number of people in need is intersectoral. 

The needs are driven by the conflict that has been going since 2011 and has led to one of the largest displacement crises in the world. The conflict has also contributed to the deterioration of the country’s economy, especially from late 2019 as a result of the combined impacts of US sanctions, COVID-19, and the collapse of the financial system in neighboring Lebanon.

The three major earthquakes that hit southeastern Türkiye and northwestern Syria in February 2023, affecting 8.8 million people in Syria alone, aggravating the existing humanitarian crisis. Further collapse of the Syrian Lira and suspension of WFP food distribution further contributed to both the increase of number of PiN and the severity of humanitarian conditions. The security situation in Syria witnessed significant deterioration in the past year as well.
The number of people who are exposed to the crisis but not affected or in needs of urgent humanitarian assistance. Since almost all in Syria are affected, the only exposed is almost zero.

The number of people who are affected by the crisis but not in needs of humanitarian assistance. This is the total population of Syria minus the number of people in needs estimated in by OCHA humanitarian needs overview for 2024.

To determine the severity levels and PiN, the the area severity from the HNO 2024 was used. This approach assumes that the whole population in a certain analysis unit is at the same level of severity. 

The remaining PiN that are not in Level 5 or Level 4 were assigned to Level 3. This is the same number as PiN in the 162 subdistricts that had a severity categorization of “Sever” at Level 3 in addition to the two subdistricts at “Stressed” Level 2. The PiN in those districts were assigned to Level 3. 

“The Distribution of People in Need by Governorate and Severity by Sub-District” map on page 39 in HNO 2024 was used to allocate those sub districts. 

Even though HNO 2024 provide severity level per sub districts, it doesn’t provide the number of PiN within those sub districts. Instead, HNO 2024 provides PiN per governorate. 

To estimate the PiN per sub district, the Food Security PiN per sub district that is provided by the Food Security Cluster was used to extrapolate those numbers.

This is done by taking the percentage of Food Security PiN for each sub district out of the whole governorate, then multiply this percentage by the PiN per governorate provided by HNO 2024 to get an estimate of PiN for each sub district.

For example, according to the area severity provided by HNO 2024, “Atareb” sub district in Aleppo governorate had a severity of Level 4. To estimate the PiN in “Atareb” who all will be placed in Level 4, we multiplied the PiN in Aleppo provided by HNO 2024 (3,505,148) with the percentage “Atareb” makes up of the total Food Security PiN provided by the Food Security Cluster (214,047/3,191,947 = 6.706%). Thus, the PiN estimate for “Atareb” will be 6.706% of the 3,505,148 PiN in Aleppo, which equals 234,844, which will all be placed at Level 4.

The reliability of this data point is set to low as the calculation used to obtain the number comes from ACAPS interpretation of JIAF figures of severity-per-analysis unit, which does not consider the diversity of severity of needs within the same unit and assume the multisectorial PiN per sub district is proportional to the Food Security PiN. Furthermore, this approach risks creating a disproportionally high Level 3 and skewing the distribution.

The new methodology for 2024 decreased Level 3 from 50.8% to 36.6%, mainly from people moving from Level 3 to Level 4. This is in alignment with the new developments of the deteriorating conditions in Syria, including deterioration in security, economy as well the impact of the earthquakes.

To determine the severity levels and PiN, the the area severity from the HNO 2024 was used. This approach assumes that the whole population in a certain analysis unit is at the same level of severity. 

According to HNO 2024,  106 sub districts had a severity categorization of “Extreme” at Level 4. 

“The Distribution of People in Need by Governorate and Severity by Sub-District” map on page 39 in HNO 2024 was used to allocate those sub districts. 

Even though HNO 2024 provide severity level per sub districts, it doesn’t provide the number of PiN within those sub districts. Instead, HNO 2024 provides PiN per governorate. 

To estimate the PiN per sub district, the Food Security PiN per sub district that is provided by the Food Security Cluster was used to extrapolate those numbers.

This is done by taking the percentage of Food Security PiN for each sub district out of the whole governorate, then multiply this percentage by the PiN per governorate provided by HNO 2024 to get an estimate of PiN for each sub district.

For example, according to the area severity provided by HNO 2024, “Atareb” sub district in Aleppo governorate had a severity of Level 4. To estimate the PiN in “Atareb” who all will be placed in Level 4, we multiplied the PiN in Aleppo provided by HNO 2024 (3,505,148) with the percentage “Atareb” makes up of the total Food Security PiN provided by the Food Security Cluster (214,047/3,191,947 = 6.706%). Thus, the PiN estimate for “Atareb” will be 6.706% of the 3,505,148 PiN in Aleppo, which equals 234,844, which will all be placed at Level 4.

The reliability of this data point is set to low as the calculation used to obtain the number comes from ACAPS interpretation of JIAF figures of severity-per-analysis unit, which does not consider the diversity of severity of needs within the same unit and assume the multisectorial PiN per sub district is proportional to the Food Security PiN. Furthermore, this approach risks creating a disproportionally high Level 3 and skewing the distribution.

The new methodology for 2024 decreased Level 3 from 50.8% to 36.6%, mainly from people moving from Level 3 to Level 4. This is in alignment with the new developments of the deteriorating conditions in Syria, including deterioration in security, economy as well the impact of the earthquakes.

According to HNO 2024 distribution of People in Need by governorate and severity by sub-district, no sub-district was in catastrophic severity category, thus, zero people were assigned to this level. This is not a significant divergent from 2023 HNO, which assigned 0.5% to this level.

The reliability of this data point is set to low as the calculation used to obtain the number comes from ACAPS interpretation of JIAF figures of severity-per-analysis unit, which does not consider the diversity of severity of needs within the same unit.

The people affected as a result of the three major earthquakes that hit southeastern Türkiye and northwestern Syria, affected around 8.8 million people in Syria alone and aggravating the existing humanitarian crisis. The earthquakes caused more than 5,900 deaths and 12,800 injures in the country. Severe basic and critical infrastructure damage included an estimated 10,600 buildings.

The Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) Cluster for Syria's shelter cluster tracked more than 108,000 displacements across NWS in February following the earthquakes, and 15,000 displacements were tracked in March.
Since more than 6 months have passed since the earthquake, the assumption is no new injuries (or significantly low) occurred due to the earthquake.
Since more than 6 months have passed since the earthquake, the assumption is no new deaths (or significantly low) occurred due to the earthquake.

Total number of fatalities in whole Syria according to ACLED dataset during the last 6 months. All type of events is included. This number includes non-civilian cases. This number doesn't include other cases of death related to the crisis that are not related to violence incidents.

Distinguishing needs as a result of the earthquake from needs caused by the conflict is complicated with not a lot of reliable sources for such estimation. A low reliability estimation using food security indicator was used. For PiN, the people targeted for food assistance activities by WFP for the EQ response was used as a proxy for PiN.
The number of people who are exposed to the crisis but not affected or in needs of urgent humanitarian assistance.
The number of people who are affected by the crisis but not in needs of humanitarian assistance.

Not enough assessment to rely on for PiN. Thus, we relied on WFP initial assessment of people in need for modality assistance in response of the Earthquake to estimate PiN. The areas affected by the Earthquake are the same areas affected by the conflict, so the humanitarian condition will be the same or worse for the EQ affected population. As there are not enough assessments on the humanitarian conditions levels for affected people by the EQ, the same percentages for the humanitarian levels for conflict crisis are used as conservative estimate. 

For moderate humanitarian conditions estimates, the percentage of people in need in Syria catagorized as in sever level per HNO 2024. This is an under-estimate as earthquakes have exacerabted humanitarian conditions in for people in need.

Not enough assessment to rely on for PiN. Thus, we relied on WFP initial assessment of people in need for modality assistance in response of the Earthquake to estimate PiN. As there are not enough assessments on the humanitarian conditions levels for affected people by the EQ, the same percentages for the humanitarian levels for conflict crisis are used as conservative estimate. 

For sever humanitarian conditions estimates, the percentage of people in need in Syria catagorized as in extreme level per HNO 2024. This is an under-estimate as earthquakes have exacerabted humanitarian conditions in for people in need.

Not enough assessment to rely on for PiN. Thus, we relied on WFP initial assessment of people in need for modality assistance in response of the Earthquake to estimate PiN. The areas affected by the Earthquake are the same areas affected by the conflict, so the humanitarian condition will be the same or worse for the EQ affected population. As there are not enough assessments on the humanitarian conditions levels for affected people by the EQ, the same percentages for the humanitarian levels for conflict crisis are used as conservative estimate. 

For extreme humanitarian conditions estimates, the percentage of people in need in Syria categorised as in catastrophic level per HNO 2024. This is an under-estimate as earthquakes have exacerbated humanitarian conditions in for people in need.

The population of Yemen in 2024
The whole of the country is affected by the complex crisis, therefore the total landmass of the country is considered.
The total population of Yemen is exposed to the conflict, therefore the total population is considered for this indicator.
The total population in Yemen is considered to be affected by the conflict at some level.

The total displaced people includes: IDPs (4,516,341), the number of refugees and asylum-seekers in Yemen as of 30 October 2023 (71628), the number of migrants per OCHA HNO 2024 (308,261), the number of IDP Returnees in Yemen as of 21 August 2019 (1,280,562).
Total number of fatalities between 01 September 2023 and 22 March 2024 due to the conflict crisis.

The figure represents the total number of fatalities between 01 Oct 2023 and 31 March 2024 for the conflict and the number reported by IOM: 12 in Oct ;19 in Nov; 25 in Dec ; 3 in Jan; 1 in Feb ; 4 in March for the migration crisis.
PiN according to HNO 2024. PiN provided by the HNO is inter sectoral. According to HNO, around 18.2m of people are in need, making around 54% of the total population in Yemen.
This represents the exposed but not affected. Since the total population in Yemen is considered affected this results in 0 in level 1.
This represent the total of affected people minus the number of people in need.

To estimate the number of people in need in level 3 we have applied the severity of needs breakdown percentages based on the 2023 HNO, taking the HNO 2024 PIN number as a reference point. We believe that this better represent the situation in Yemen. In the HNO 2023, 38% of PIN were in severe/level 3 severity, therefore 38% of 18.2 million= 6,916,000 million people.

To estimate the number of people in need in level 4 we have applied the severity of needs breakdown percentages based on the 2023 HNO, taking the HNO 2024 PIN number as a reference point. We believe that this better represent the situation in Yemen. In the HNO 2023, 34% of PIN were in extreme/level 4 severity, therefore 34% of 18.2 million= 6,188,000 million people.

To estimate the number of people in need in level 5 we have applied the severity of needs breakdown percentages based on the 2023 HNO, taking the HNO 2024 PIN number as a reference point. We believe that this better represent the situation in Yemen. In the HNO 2023, 28% of PIN were in catastrophic/level 5 severity, therefore 28% of 18.2 million= 5,096,000 million people.

Source and Date: UNHCR accessed on 15/03/2024; IPC 05/02/2024; HDX 30/06/2023; OCHA 01/02/2024; Euro-Med Human Rights Monitor 22/05/2022
Justification: The complex crisis in Yemen affects all five population groups: Host, non-host, IDP, refugees and asylum seekers, others of concern (such as migrants).
